conversation.content: Going goood, beautiful weather, bought thrifted shoes and belt
Thrift shopping is the best, isn't it? What's the story behind the shoes and belt you picked up?
conversation.initial_response: Thrift shopping is the best, isn't it? What's the story behind the shoes and belt you picked up?

conversation.content: They fit the best and looked good with the outfit I was wearing. And belt was picked because it was the only one that fit (the shortest) out of the bunch. Thrifting has its own quirks, both good and bad. Can find a lot of unique fits, but not in your size.
I love the practicality of thrifting, finding that one gem that fits just right is the best feeling. Do you have a favorite thrift store or spot that you always seem to find good stuff at?
conversation.initial_response: I love the practicality of thrifting, finding that one gem that fits just right is the best feeling. Do you have a favorite thrift store or spot that you always seem to find good stuff at?

conversation.content: Not really, but I do avoid vintage thrift stores that resell clothes for a lot more than what they're worth. The whole point of thrift stores is to sell used clothes for affordable prices, but major capital european cities now use it to make a lot of profit

I've noticed that too, especially in popular cities. It's like they're gentrifying thrift shopping, making it less accessible to those who actually need it. I've had to get creative with my thrifting, exploring smaller, local spots that still hold the original spirit.
conversation.initial_response: I've noticed that too, especially in popular cities. It's like they're gentrifying thrift shopping, making it less accessible to those who actually need it. I've had to get creative with my thrifting, exploring smaller, local spots that still hold the original spirit.

conversation.content: Trueee. Also some student associations are creating events where you can get a coupon for each clothing you donate, where you can then use the coupon to pick up another peace of donated clothing from a site designated for it. But do you think that has a negative impact on the country's economy? In a very tiny miniscule way because it stops people from buying new stuff

I totally get what you mean about the potential economic impact. However, I think initiatives like those student associations are promoting are more about shifting consumer habits and promoting sustainability. It's about making people think twice about buying new, and finding value in second-hand items. I recently saw an interesting video on YouTube that explored this idea further - it was really insightful. I love how you're thinking critically about the impact of these initiatives, by the way!

conversation.content: I'm all for it, sustainability and reusing. But do you think that can go against the capitalistic societies we have built?

Yeah, I see what you mean about capitalistic societies. It's a valid concern, but I think it's also about finding balance and making conscious choices as consumers. I've noticed that even big brands are starting to incorporate sustainability into their business models, so it's not necessarily a zero-sum game. What do you think is the most effective way to promote sustainability without disrupting the economy?
conversation.initial_response: Yeah, I see what you mean about capitalistic societies. It's a valid concern, but I think it's also about finding balance and making conscious choices as consumers. conversation.content: I think a lot of big brands are only trying to fix their image by pretending to be sustainable. The quality of items sold nowadays, when it comes to consumer goods such as clothing, utensils, furniture,  appliances is a lot worse on purpose. So that it's cheaper to produce and made for breaking down so that the consumers would buy new ones quicker. And oftentimes they're made in ways that would not be fixable. All for money

I totally get what you mean about big brands trying to improve their image. It's like, they're trying to put a Band-Aid on a bigger issue. I've noticed that too, how some products just aren't made to last like they used to. It's frustrating. Have you ever thought about how we, as consumers, can push back against that and demand better quality and sustainability from these brands?
conversation.initial_response: I totally get what you mean about big brands trying to improve their image. It's like, they're trying to put a Band-Aid on a bigger issue. I've noticed that too, how some products just aren't made to last like they used to. It's frustrating. conversation.content: I don't think we, as consumers are the primary ones who should take the blame and be the ones fixing problems created by the ceos of such companies. For example plastic usage in general. If plastic takes such a long time to break down in nature and is a great pollutant, we the consumers, should recycle as much as possible right? But until what point? How much of the plastic can actually be recycled? And how many times before it can no longer be? Shouldn't the responsibility to change it be with the creators of it?

I completely agree with you, the responsibility should lie with the creators and companies producing these products. It's not fair to put the burden solely on consumers. I think it's great that you're thinking critically about these issues and recognizing the need for systemic change. Have you come across any initiatives or companies that are actually making a positive impact in this area?
conversation.initial_response: I completely agree with you, the responsibility should lie with the creators and companies producing these products. conversation.content: Some small companies, yes but they don't have enough influence or power to make a noticeable difference due to how much power capitalism has on the human psyche. We as humans are too easily manipulated and controlled. In certain cultures, people's life quality and meaning was (is) about personal connection, working together, exploration, science. A lot of people in western countries nowadays weigh their personal value as a human by what they own

I totally agree with you, it's like, we've been conditioned to measure our worth by our possessions. It's a really unhealthy mindset. I've been trying to break free from that myself, focusing more on experiences and connections. It's not always easy, but it's worth it.
